abstract.p: Joanne Starkey reviews Cerulean Restaurant in East Hampton, Long Island; photo (M)

block.p: THE idea is not new: A resort or restaurant in the Caribbean, where winter is the high season, opens a spot in the Hamptons and sends its chef and staff there for a busy summer. This year's entry is the Cerulean Restaurant, a spin-off of the Cerulean Villa in Anguilla.

THE idea is not new: A resort or restaurant in the Caribbean, where winter is the high season, opens a spot in the Hamptons and sends its chef and staff there for a busy summer. This year's entry is the Cerulean Restaurant, a spin-off of the Cerulean Villa in Anguilla.

The newcomer makes its home in the 1770 House, a historic inn on Main Street in East Hampton. The dining rooms of the antique-filled inn have had a face lift. The dark wood ceiling beams remain but everything else is airy, light and tropical. Tropical here does not mean plastic palm trees. The look is sleek and sophisticated.

The white walls are dotted with original art and partly covered with a colorful fabric depicting Caribbean women with laden baskets on their heads. Tables are topped with snowy white napery and shallow bowls holding floating candles and flowers. A fireplace filled with flickering candles is a focal point. Tall wicker chairs with comfortable cushioned seats complete the picture.
The staff is sharp. The servers, in cerulean blue shirts, know the menu, describe dishes accurately and make few mistakes. They also take the time to be friendly.

The restaurant calls its food tropical-Asian-Caribbean and emphasizes seafood. The menu is small and manageable (five appetizers, six entrees). It is also limited. I loved nearly everything I tasted, but many diners will be hard-pressed to find something they like. Five of the six entrees are fin fish, the last is a beef tenderloin-lobster tail combination. All of the appetizers, with the exception of the soup, are fish or seafood. A person at our table wished aloud for a simple green salad.

Those caveats aside, the food is wonderful: lightly cooked fish, sweet seafood and just enough Asian and island spins to make it interesting. Tops among the openers is the warm lobster salad, a mound of sauteed fresh soybeans and shiitake mushrooms piled upon arugula and crowned with lobster and balsamic vinaigrette. Also turning heads was the sushi-quality soy-cured tuna mated with black sesame-dotted green beans, segments of orange and a drizzled ginger emulsion.

Three other successes were rouget escabeche (cold poached fish in a spicy marinade) escorted by fiddlehead ferns and a mango chutney; an offering of cold, sliced, cooked monkfish foie gras with a sour mango relish and a clump of mizuna, and a marinated seafood tasting (scallops ceviche, braised octopus in tomato-lime brine and three small oysters on the half shell with different toppings). A tasty cold soup, pumpkin vichyssoise, came in last only because of the exalted company it kept.

Cerulean serves the ultimate surf and turf: a flavorful grilled beef tenderloin paired with a sweet Maine lobster tail. A fragile potato galette (a ring of paper-thin fried potato slices), sauteed chanterelles and a Szechuan pepper sauce complete the magic plate. Of the fish, the top pick is the perfectly cooked Chilean sea bass perched on a hash of corn, tiny potato cubes and crab meat, with baby spinach and a warm citrus vinaigrette. Also memorable are the monkfish medallions presented with roasted figs, Swiss chard and a sweet-tangy pepper-Port sauce.

Desserts are just as special. Each had its champion. Chocolate lovers found the moist chocolate bread pudding with banana ice cream and buttered rum sauce a must. My personal favorite was the ginger panna cotta. The satiny custard sported a grilled mango topper one night, a white peach compote another. The pineapple tatin, a crisp open-faced tart with coconut sorbet and mango sauce, drew sighs of ''wonderful,'' as did the mixed berry shortcake with white chocolate ice cream. The shortcake was really a construction of crisp shortbread cookies and a compote of red and yellow raspberries, blackberries, blueberries and strawberries.
Cerulean Restaurant 143 Main Street at the 1770 House, East Hampton. (631) 329-5550.

ATMOSPHERE -- Sophisticated, tropical splendor in a historic inn. SERVICE -- On their toes. SOUND LEVEL Comfortable. RECOMMENDED DISHES -- Lobster salad, soy-cured tuna, marinated seafood tasting, monkfish foie gras, rouget escabeche, beef tenderloin-lobster tail combination, sea bass, monkfish with figs, all desserts. WINE LIST -- A medium-size, sharply marked-up list (the least expensive bottle of red is $33) of French, American and Australian selections. PRICE RANGE -- Appetizers, $9 to $15; entrees, $24 to $37; desserts, $7 to $9. CREDIT CARDS -- All the majors. HOURS -- 5:30 to 10:30 p.m. Wednesday through Monday. Closed Tuesdays. RESERVATIONS -- A must. WHEELCHAIR ACCESSIBILITY -- Four steps at entrance.
